Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit in which the voltage across a capacitor undergoes a Fourier transformation, defined by \\(F(v(t)) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty v(t) e^{-i\\omega t} dt\\), where \\(v(t)\\) is a voltage function of time, and \\(\\omega\\) is the angular frequency. We're analyzing the impact of the operation defined by the transfer function \\(H(\\omega) = \\frac{1}{1 + i\\omega\\tau}\\), with a constant \\(\\tau\\).

If the transfer function \\(H(\\omega)\\) is applied to the Fourier transformed voltage \\(F(v(t))\\) initially, and the system is allowed to evolve without further intervention, will the resulting time-domain signal, found by an inverse Fourier transform, be the same as if \\(v(t)\\) had been directly processed without undergoing \\(H(\\omega)\\)?
Explanation: The application of \\(H(\\omega)\\) on \\(F(v(t))\\) alters the spectral components of the voltage, effectively filtering the original signal. When this modified spectral representation is transformed back using the inverse Fourier transform, the resulting time-domain waveform differs from the unfiltered \\(v(t)\\).
causal_map_prompt: You are an expert in causal reasoning. Given the following problem description and question, identify all relevant variables and describe their direct causal relationships.Your output should be a clear causal map in textual form, listing directed causal links as "A → B" (meaning A directly causes B).Avoid redundancy or duplicate links. List only distinct and meaningful causal relations. Do not provide any final answer to the question. Focus only on extracting the causal structure. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "A → B; C → D; ..."}.
causal_map: transfer function H(ω) → Fourier transformed voltage F(v(t)); τ → transfer function H(ω); v(t) → Fourier transformed voltage F(v(t)); v(t) → time-domain signal; F(v(t)) → inverse Fourier transform → time-domain signal; H(ω) → inverse Fourier transform; inverse Fourier transform → time-domain signal
